Kansas City police on Friday continued to look for two armed robbers who fatally shot a store employee Thursday afternoon even though the victim didn't appear to offer any resistance.
 
 The deadly holdup at Bledsoe's Rental, which rents tools and equipment, occurred about 2:10 p.m. at 5025 Prospect Ave.
 
 Police said one of the two gunmen forced one employee to the back of the store to get money. The other gunman stayed up front and guarded David W. Bledsoe, 50, as Bledsoe sat in a chair.
 
 Bledsoe and the gunman "exchanged words," police said. Bledsoe said something to the effect of, "You're not going to shoot me," police said, but then the gunman did just that.
 
 The other employee did not witness the shooting, police said. The gunmen fled with an undisclosed amount of cash.
 
 Despite being wounded, Bledsoe chased the gunmen. He hopped in his truck and followed them before pulling over and collapsing. He later died.
 
 Police said they don't think Bledsoe resisted or challenged the gunman.
 
 "This is a business robbery that went terribly wrong," said Police Sgt. Richard Sharp.
 
 Homicide Capt. Floyd Mitchell called Bledsoe a "truly innocent victim."
